subject: Re: [junit] use of setUp and tearDown

Cedric Beust wrote:
>>From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On 
>>Behalf Of Jim Stuttard
> 
> 
>>>setUp() fails and JUnit still invokes your tests anyway (and they will
>>>fail)
>>
>>So there is no way I can catch an exception and stop JUnit 
>>from running the tests?
> 
> 
> No.

Actually, that turns out not to be the case...

First off, if there's a failure in setUp(), then the test isn't run. And, 
because you shouldn't put asserts into setUp, a "failure" is really an 
error (error = unexpected exception). Errors are flagged differently from 
failures by most JUnit test runners (although, in the GUI ones, they still 
cause red bars).

So if setUp() fails for one test, that test will not be executed. The UI or 
report will say that it was run, but that it had an error. So, you'll get a 
report with something like "101TESTS, 101 TESTS RAN, 1 FAILURE, 100 ERRORS".

You can do the same thing for a suite of tests: simply wrap the suite in a 
TestDecorator (or the TestSetup subclass), and put setUp logic there. This 
will be invoked once for the suite, and if it fails, none of the tests are 
run. In this event, you'd get something like "101 TESTS, 1 TEST RAN, 1 
FAILURE, 0 ERRORS".

And if you want to change any of this behaviour, override either 
run(TestResult) or runBare() in TestCase.

Robert.
